findings.title: Mishandled exceptions and call stack limits
Reentrancy and cross-function vulnerabilities
findings.description: execution of the function `transfer()` on a user-provided token contract may result in re-entrancy attacks on the contract.

findings.title: Denial of service / logical oversights
findings.description: A possibility of carrying out a denial of service attack on exits.

findings.title: Business logic contradicting the specification
findings.description: The code does not fully adhere to the provided specifications.

findings.title: Code clones, functionality duplication
findings.description: The codebase relies on the clone-and-own approach for code reuse, which involves copying and adjusting open source code at one's own discretion. This approach may involve risks as the code may not follow best practices, contain security vulnerabilities, or include intentionally or unintentionally modified upstream libraries.

findings.title: Gas Usage / `for` Loop Concerns
findings.description: High gas costs may prevent users from wanting to use the smart contract or even prevent the contract from providing services entirely.

findings.title: Arbitrary token minting
findings.description: An attacker can mint arbitrary tokens due to a vulnerability in the contract.
